title: How to Drink Pink Gin

steps.headline: Combine pink gin and bitters for a classic cocktail.
steps.description: When pink gin first originated, it was meant to be mixed with just bitters. Mix together 2 fluid ounces (59 mL) of pink gin and 4 to 6 dashes of bitters in a glass full of ice. Stir them together until your mixture is cold and then strain it into a glass. You can serve your drink warm if you prefer. Simply mix the pink gin and bitters in a glass without ice and serve it immediately.

steps.headline: Choose a pink gin and tonic to keep it simple.
steps.description: Gin and tonics are a classic gin cocktail that have many flavor variations. Substitute regular gin for pink gin and combine it with tonic water to taste. Add a few slices of strawberries to keep this drink looking and tasting sweet. Pink gin is slightly sweeter than normal gin, so it tastes great with tonic water.

steps.headline: Try a pink gin lemonade for a summery drink.
steps.description: Fill a wine glass with ice. Add 50 millilitres (1.7  fl oz) of pink gin and 150 millilitres (5.1  fl oz) of lemonade to the glass and stir them together. Add frozen or fresh strawberry slices to flavor and garnish your drink.Tip: Make this drink fizzy by adding lemon lime soda instead of lemonade.

steps.headline: Make pink gin punch for a large gathering.
steps.description: Fill a large pitcher with ice. Stir together 300 millilitres (10  fl oz) of pink gin, 300 millilitres (10  fl oz) of cranberry juice, 300 millilitres (10  fl oz) of lemon juice, and 60 millilitres (2.0  fl oz) of simple syrup in the pitcher. Add some strawberries or raspberries if you’d like to. This punch serves about 8 to 10 people if everyone has 1 glass.

methods.name: Putting a Twist on Classic Cocktails

steps.headline: Try a pink Sonic for a sweet drink.
steps.description: Mix together 1.5 fluid ounces (44 mL) of pink gin, 2 fluid ounces (59 mL) of tonic water and 2 fluid ounces (59 mL) of club soda. Stir your ingredients together with a spoon so they are fully mixed. Add a few cubes of ice to your glass and garnish it with a strawberry on the side. Use a metal straw to sip your drink. Pink sonics are notoriously sweet, so they are good for fruity drink lovers or people who don’t love the taste of gin.

steps.headline: Create a pink martini for a twist on a classic drink.
steps.description: Combine 2 fluid ounces (59 mL) of pink gin with 1 fluid ounce (30 mL) of vermouth and a splash of bitters in a mixing glass with ice. Stir your ingredients until the mixture is chilled. Strain your drink into a martini glass and garnish it with a lemon peel.Tip: If you like citrus, squeeze your lemon peel over your drink before you use it as a garnish.

steps.headline: Make a pink French ‘75 for a sparkling cocktail.
steps.description: Mix together 1.5 fluid ounces (44 mL) of pink gin,  ⁄2 fluid ounce (15 mL) of fresh lemon juice, and ⁄2 fluid ounce (15 mL) of simple syrup in a cocktail shaker with ice. Shake your mixture for about 1 minute, then strain it into a champagne flute. Add 2.5 fluid ounces (74 mL) of sparkling wine and garnish your drink with a strawberry and a lemon peel. This is a classic drink for celebrations, like weddings and anniversaries.

steps.headline: Try a pink gin gimlet for a grapefruit taste.
steps.description: Fill a cocktail shaker with ice. Add the juice of 1 lime and ½ of a grapefruit. Pour in 1.5 fluid ounces (44 mL) of pink gin and 0.75 fluid ounces (22 mL) of simple syrup. Shake the cocktail shaker for about 1 minute to combine your ingredients and pour your drink into a martini glass. You can garnish with fresh herbs, or use a slice of the other half of the grapefruit to put in your drink.

steps.headline: Add strawberries to your drink to enhance the sweet notes.
steps.description: Strawberries go great with pink gin since pink gin has a subtle berry flavor to it already. Cut up strawberry slices and add them to the sides of your glass as a garnish. Or, freeze strawberry slices to use as ice cubes in your pink gin cocktails. Strawberries also look great with pink gin.

steps.headline: Put fresh herb sprigs on your drink to make it more like classic gin.
steps.description: Normal gin has a more juniper, herbaceous flavor to it, while pink gin brings notes of sweet raspberries to its drinks. If you want to keep your drink more classic, add a few sprigs of rosemary or lavender to your drink.Tip: Fresh herbs have a much stronger flavor than dried ones. Herbs go great with pink gin and tonics.

steps.headline: Place lemon or lime peels on the sides of your drink to bring out a citrus flavor.
steps.description: Classic gin cocktails often have lemon or lime garnishes to add citrus flavors and cut the bitterness of gin. You can keep the classic flavors going by adding lemon or lime peels to your pink gin cocktails. Cut your citrus fruit into slices and cut the pulp off of the peel with a knife. Twist the peel into a curled shape and attach it to the side of your drink.

steps.headline: Garnish with a grapefruit peel to tone down the sweet flavor of pink gin.
steps.description: Grapefruits are notoriously bitter, so they are the perfect companion to pink gin since it is so sweet. Cut a grapefruit into slices, then carefully remove the peel with a knife. Add it to your drink to cut the sweetness and enjoy your pink gin cocktail. If you like the flavor of grapefruit, squeeze some into your gin cocktail before you drink it.
